In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Here's a function in Julia called `wrap_string` that takes an input string and wraps it such that no line exceeds a specified `text_width`. By default, the `text_width` is set to 10.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    wrapped_lines = []
    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            push!(wrapped_lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            if current_line == ""
                current_line = word
            else
                current_line *= " " * word
            end
        end
    end

    if current_line != ""
        push!(wrapped_lines, current_line)
    end

    return join(wrapped_lines, "\n")
end

# Example Usage
text = "Julia is a high-level, high-performance programming language for technical computing."
println(wrap_string(text))
```

In this example, the `wrap_string` function will split the input text by spaces into words, and then it will iterate through those words, assembling lines of text that do not exceed the specified `text_width`. When adding another word would exceed the `text_width`, it starts a new line.

Here is how the output may look for the given example with the default `text_width` of 10:

```
Julia is a
high-level,
high-perform
ance
programmin
g language
for
technical
computing.
```

Remember that if you want a different `text_width`, you can specify it as an argument when calling the function, e.g., `wrap_string(text; text_width=15)`.
